RMPDescription: Sent to Welco Acety. Jsmith to submit separately

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description:
The Welco Acetylene Corp. facility in Newark, New Jersey is a industrial gas plant that handles and / or stores acetylene Gas. The Newark facility receives acetylene in bulk trailers.  Facility also produces acetylene through calcium carbide generation, and then compresses it into cylinders for distribution by truck.

Regulated Substances:
This facility uses, manufactures or stores a chemical listed in part 68 of tile 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, beyond a threshold quantity, as established by the EPA;
-Acetylene which is compressed into individual cylinders for sale to customers.

Accidental Release Prevention Policy:
Welco Acetylene Corp. is dedicated to being the best performing  industrial gas company in all aspects of our business, including Safety, Health and Environmental Affairs. Our Safety, health and environmental policies call for a commitment to protecting the health & safety of our employees, neighbors and the surrounding environment. This is a basis for engineering  and construction programs that produce equipment and process systems that minimize the possibility of accidental releases and operational safety programs that ensure the safe operation of our facility. Welco Acetylene Corp. is committed to continuous improvement of these programs.

Prevention program:
    In accordance with OSHA? s Process Safety Management standard and EPA?s Risk Management Rule, our Newark, N.J. facility has a comprehensive accident prevention program in place. This program is built around safety concepts such as;
?Technical documentation of Process Safety Information, describing the physical properties of the hazardous substances, the safety systems in place to control these substances and the critical operating perameters of the associated systems and equipment.
?Procedures and programs to develop, maintain and control key program elements such as process operations, equipment mechanical integrity, employee training, management of change, hot

work permits, incident investigation and contractor activity.
?Initial and periodic review of new or modified processes through management of change programs that include Process Hazard Analysis and pre-start up procedures

Welco Acetylene Corp. has a employees participation program that promotes involvement in the process safety program and helps ensure understanding of facility specific elements of the safety program.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
-In addition to the required prevention program, we have implemented safety features specific to the covered process at our facility. Some of these features include:
?An incident alarm system
?Remote emergency shut-down stations
?Heat activated deluge system in process and storage areas.

Five Year Accident History:
-The Newark facility accident history indicates safe operation of our covered process over the last 5 years. There were no covered process releases that resulted in an EPA RMP recordable accident. 


Emergency Response Programs:
-Welco Acetylene Corp. has an emergency response program in place to minimize the effects of accidental release of regulated substances on employees, the public and the environment. The Newark facility will be a ? non-responding facility? as defined in section 8.1 of the CEPPO General Guidance For Risk Management Programs ( July 1998). Employees will only respond to minor incidents>
-For other then minor incidents Welco Acetylene Corp. has in place an emergency response plan in coordination with the Newark Fire Department ? Ferry Street station.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
-Welco Acetylene Corp. has a commitment that is expressed in a company wide goal of Zero Accidents and Zero Injuries. We look to continuously improve the safety of our processes using recommendations developed through our prevention program and the solicitation of safety suggestions from our employees.
-There are currently no major projects for safety improvement that have reached the planning stage
